content.description: Steep climb.  Watch for loose rock on the beginning.
content.protection: Helmet for belayer. 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: There is a lot of loose rock at the start and less as you get past first bolt.  Crimpy moves in the middle then gets easier at the top.
content.protection: Helmet for belayer.  6 bolts to 2 bolt anchor that is shared with Cobble Stoned
content.location: to the right of Cobble Stoned 5.10c

content.description: High first bolt.  Watch for loose cobbles at begging section.
content.protection: Helmet for belayer.  5 bolts to a 1 bolt anchor

content.description: Small finger crack protects easy face climbing. Cruz is about halfway with poor protection and the climb ends by topping out the cliff.
content.protection:
Small gear and one #2 cam

Belay from tree at the top and walk off to the East.
content.location: Located 80 ft to the left of Cobble Stoned and 60 feet to the left of Sheeka.

content.description:
Stick clip recommended. Challenging moves up off the deck to the first bolt. Some less advanced climbers might have quite a bit of difficulty on this start making it feel much harder than ~5.10a. Follow the bolt line while being mindful of the less solid cobbles to the right side along the arete. Crux might be moving through after clipping the 3rd bolt, unless getting started off the deck is your crux.

Route got the moniker from the curious little hummingbird that visited me in the middle of route development.
content.protection: 4 bolts plus 2 single ring anchors. Stick clip for bolt 1 is recommended.
content.location:
From the four original sport routes at the Parowan Gap crag, move left through the tunnel between the wall and the rock island then turn the corner to the right once you've emerged. Two new routes are located here on the face between the arete edge and the corner crack (which I believe is Draney's

Sheeka

5.7 noted in Goss' book).

Belayer be mindful of additional cobbles cleaning off of the route from the climber. Be prudent, wear a helmet at Parowan Gap, Shinobe and Roller Rink crags!

content.description: Step up off the deck near the start of the corner crack trending slightly right to the first bolt, then slightly left into a shallow diagonal scoop to the second bolt. From there head straight up using mostly pockets to the smoother rock layer from the last bolt to the anchors.
content.location:
From the four original sport routes at the Parowan Gap crag, move left through the tunnel between the wall and the rock island then turn the corner to the right once you've emerged. Two new routes are located here on the face between the arete edge and the corner crack (which I believe is Draney's

Sheeka

5.7 noted in Goss' book).

content.description: The bolted route that is all the way to the left looking at the wall.  The hardest part is not knocking any loose cobble stone on your partner.
content.protection: Helmet for your belayer.  4 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: Lot's of cobbles and pockets from fallen cobbles for the first 3/4 of the route, then the crux is getting to the anchors over the last bolt as the rock changes from cobbles to a smooth stone for 6-8 feet (this is where the crimps come into play).
content.location: Left-most route at the Parowan Gap crag. Go past the original 4 routes, then either through the tunnel or around the leaning boulder left of these routes to the other side where there are now 3 moderate routes - two on the right side of the corner and this new one just left of it.
